Award.AwardTitle: Studies in Nuclear Physics and Fundamental Interactions at Indiana University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award derives its intellectual merit from our leadership in addressing the following scientific questions: (1) How the angular momentum of the proton is distributed among its parts. The spinning of the three quarks inside the proton only accounts for a small part of the proton's angular momentum. The rest must be somewhere: we search for it in the "gluons" which hold the quarks inside the proton. (2) Why the Big Bang left the universe with the surplus of matter over anti-matter that we see today. Instead of an equal mixture of matter and antimatter, the universe has much more matter: this is not understood. If extremely small separations of the positive and negative electrical charges within the neutron or electron are discovered, it could give an important clue. (3) Whether neutrinos behave oddly at low energy. Hints have been seen in earlier experiments: we will pursue the leads and develop new technologies to measure neutrinos. (4) How strong the weak force really is. We will use neutrons to precisely calibrate the weak force.

As broader impacts of our work, our research activities educate the next generation of skilled and innovative PhD scientists for jobs in research and teaching universities, industry and national labs, and medical and computer technology. We have participated in the NSF REU program for 22 years and in addition we host several undergraduate students and visiting faculty from undergraduate institutions who conduct collaborative research. We mentor our postdocs to facilitate their future entry into teaching and research institutions and the scientific community. We develop undergraduate laboratories emphasizing nuclear technology, bring undergraduates on field trips to IUCF and assist with programs that encourage pre-college participation in the Indiana University science curriculum. We reach out to the local community through a variety of activities that awaken the interest of students in our local public school system, by visiting local high school science classes, acting as judges in local science fairs and for the State Science Olympiad, and presenting physics demonstrations at the Indiana State Fair. We actively recruit female and minority applicants for positions at all levels within the group and the physics department and serve on selection committees for graduate research fellowships for women and for faculty searches. We work to make our activities known to the public at large through laboratory tours and Open Houses, science caf√© discussions, and items of public interest in the media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nuclear physics group at Indiana University has made significant progress in answering important scientific questions involving the strong nuclear force and in searching for possible new interactions in Nature. We concentrated our efforts on experiments that directly address these four key areas of inquiry:

(1) How do the quarks and gluons that make up the proton contribute to its observable properties? We used signals from a large detector we built earlier and installed at Brookhaven National Lab to gain new information on how the quarks and gluons in the proton are spinning. We also used data from a detector at the KEK laboratory in Japan to learn about how quarks that are violently struck inside the proton collect other particles as they try to escape. 

(2) How do neutrinos ‘oscillate’ into different types and interact with matter? Are neutrinos and antineutrinos really the same? We measured neutrinos of different types turning into each other using both neutrino and antineutrino beams from Fermilab. We measured the probability for neutrinos to create reactions in carbon nuclei, discovered a 30% higher rate than predicted by theory and confirmed this discovery with independent data. In an underground lab in New Mexico, we helped observe the slowest radioactive decay process ever measured in an isotope of xenon and searched for a process that emits no neutrinos: the latter event can only happen if neutrinos and antineutrinos are really the same. 

(3) Can we find evidence for an electric dipole moment in a fundamental particle, a result that would require violating some of the most basic symmetries of nature? An electric dipole moment, which comes from a separation of positive and negative electric charge, is forbidden for fundamental particles unless the laws of physics depend on the direction of flow of time. We prepared for future experiments in the neutron and electron.

(4) How can we use the strong nuclear force to unravel the details of much weaker forces? We searched for violations of mirror symmetry at the NIST lab near Washington DC by looking to see if spinning neutrons would corkscrew while moving through liquid helium. We took the first data on an experiment at the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge lab to seach for the weak interaction between the neutron and the proton. We discovered new ways to slow down neutrons at Los Alamos National Lab which can allow us to conduct many precise experiments. We measuerd the protons and electrons in neutron decay at NIST to determine the relative odds that they are emitted in the same or opposite directions.

In addition to these scientific results, we also in parallel developed new technologies to improve our ability to perform more precise experiments in the future. Examples of these new technologies include better ways to detect neutrinos and high energy neutrons and more efficient electronics to process the required information, electrically quiet high voltage sources, extremely low-noise computer data acquisition systems, and more precise ways to track electrically-charged particles in head-to-head collisions of high energy protons.  

The Indiana nuclear physics group has a long tradition of training outstanding undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs who succeed both as scientific researchers and educators and also in professional roles in the private sector.  Over the last two years four IU students received their Ph.D. degrees.  Of the four, three are now postdoctoral research associates at universities or national labs and one is employed in the private sector in the energy field. Roughly a quarter of our students have been recipients of either national or university-wide awards or fellowships.
